Title: Perks of Being a Wallflower, The
Author: Stephen Chbosky

Replies.Reply: Dear Friend, I am writing to you because she said you listen and understand and didn't try to sleep with that person at that party even though you could have.
I hope it's okay for me to think that.
But tomorrow is my first day of high school ever, and I really need to turn things around this year.
So, I have a plan.
As I enter the school for the first time, I will visualize what it will be like on the last day of my senior year.
... 1,385 days from now.
Just 1,385 days.
In the meantime, I'd hoped that my sister Candace and her boyfriend Derek would have let me eat lunch with their earth club.
When my sister said no, I thought maybe my old friend Susan would want to have lunch with me.
On the bright side, one senior decided to make fun of the teacher instead of the freshmen. He even drew on Mr. Callahan's legendary goatee with a grease pencil.
I felt really bad for Patrick. He wasn't saying the impersonation to be mean or anything. He was just trying to make us freshmen feel better.
My last class of the day is advanced English, and I'm excited to finally start learning with the smartest kids in the school...
Thank you, sir, but if my English teacher is the only friend I make today, that would be sort of depressing.
Don't worry, Mr. Anderson.     I'm okay.
Well, I have 1,384 days to go. And just so I say it to someone, high school is even worse than middle school.
If my parents ask me about it, I probably won't tell them the truth because I don't want them to worry that I might get bad again.

If my Aunt Helen were still here, I could talk to her. And I know she would understand how I am both happy and sad, and I'm still trying to figure out how that could be. I just hope I make a friend soon. Love always, Charlie.
Yes, sir.    I sure do.
Are you sure?
Hey... Patrick.
My dad's building it.
No.   I'll sit if that's okay.
So, uh... you like football?
Then, maybe you know my broth--
Uh... Charlie... Kelmeckis.
Is that what they call him?
I think The Smiths are my favorite.
Asleep. It's from Louder Than Bombs. I heard it on Pony Tail Derek's mix tape.
I could make a copy for you.
Yeah. They're great.
That's okay.
My Aunt Helen said I should be a writer, but I don't know what I'd write about.
You guys look happy together. How long have you been boyfriend and girlfriend?
What?
I'm sorry.     I don't know what that means.
No problem. Thanks for the ride. Hey...
Okay.   Bye.
What are you doing?
Like Aunt Helen's boyfriends?
Are you sure it's okay that I come?
Is that Brad Hays?
But he's a popular kid.
Thank you. I was so hungry at the dance.
Have you guys felt this carpet?     This carpet feels so darn good.

High school? Bullshit. The cafeteria is called the Nutrition Center. And people wear their letter jackets even when it's 98 degrees out. And why do they give out letters for marching band? That's not a sport, and we all know it.
And Mary Elizabeth, I think you're really going to regret that haircut when you look back at old photographs.
I'm really sorry. That sounded like a compliment in my head.
I just really want a milkshake.
Sam, you have such pretty brown eyes, the kind of pretty that deserves to make a big deal about itself. You know what I mean?
What a great word. Milkshake. It's like when you say your name over and over again in the mirror, and after awhile, it sounds crazy.
Me? No. My best friend Michael. His dad was a big drinker. So, he hated all that stuff. Parties, too.
Oh, he shot himself last May.
I kind of wish he'd left a note.    You know what I mean?
Where's the bathroom?
Charlie.     Charlie.   Weird.
Woah.
I didn't see anything.
"Like a cake." That's what Bob said.
Our little secret.     Agreed.
I look forward to that big talk.
Isn't this the best milkshake, Alice?
What did I do?
Never.
What is she doing?
I feel infinite.
Dear Friend, I'm sorry I haven't written for awhile, but I've been trying hard not to be a loser.
For example, I am trying to participate by listening to Sam's collection of big rock ballads and thinking about love.

I am also studying extra books outside of class. As it turns out, Mr. Anderson is a writer. He even had a play put up in New York once, which I think is very impressive. He and his wife might go back there after this year. I know this is selfish, but I really hope he doesn't.
My favorite time, though, is lunch because I get to see Sam and Patrick. We spend the time working on Mary Elizabeth's fanzine about music and The Rocky Horror Picture Show. It's called Punk Rocky.

Her best friend Alice loves vampires and wants to go to film school. She also steals jeans from the mall. I don't know why because her family is rich, but I'm trying not to be judgemental. Especially since I know how they were all there for Patrick last year. Patrick never likes to be serious, so it took me awhile to get what happened.
When he was a junior, Patrick started seeing Brad on the weekends in secret. I guess it was hard, too, because Brad had to get drunk every time they fooled around.
Then, Monday in school, Brad would say, "Man, I was so wasted. I don't remember a thing." This went on for 7 months.
When they finally did it, Brad said he loved Patrick. Then, he started to cry.
Patrick was eventually able to help Brad get sober. I asked Patrick if he felt sad that he had to keep it a secret, and he said no because at least now, Brad doesn't have to get drunk to love him.

I think that I understand because I really like Sam. I asked my sister about her, and she said that when Sam was a freshman, the upper classmen used to get her drunk at parties. I guess she had a reputation. But I don't care. I'd hate for her to judge me based on what I used to be like.
So, I've been making her a mix tape so she will know how I feel.
Ah, shit!
Hey.    Are you okay?
You can take them again.
I'll help you study for the next one.
Yeah, of course.
Just a mix tape. No big deal. My parents have a pretty good stereo. It's all about that night in the tunnel. I couldn't find that song we were listening to, but I'm still searching for it, so--
Really?
No.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Mr. Anderson... can I ask you something?
Why do nice people choose the wrong people to date?
Can we make them know they deserve more?
Hey, Sam. I didn't see you come in.     You want to work on probabilities and statistics?
Hey, dad.    Can I have 30 dollars?
Sam is doing secret santa. It's her favorite thing in the world. Please.
Thanks.
Thanks.
You too, Mr. Anderson.
Where's Craig?
I'm sorry we won't be seeing him tonight.
Okay. Uh, I have received socks, pants, a shirt, and a belt. I was ordered to wear them all tonight. So, I'm guessing my secret santa is Mary Elizabeth.
I don't know. She bosses people around sometimes.
Sorry.
You got me clothes?     Why?
Can you hand these out while I'm gone?
Where are we going?
Is this your room?    It's so cool.
You got me a present?
I don't know what to say.
That's okay. I'm just sorry you have to go back and visit your dad.
You are.
No.
Well, it hasn't worked so far.
No.   What about you?
No! Your first kiss...
Was he your first boyfriend?
It's true.     You can do it.
My Aunt... she had that same thing done to her, too. And she turned her life around.
She was my favorite person in the world... until now.
I love you, too.
Have a good time at your mom's.
Thank you, Patrick.
Hey.
How are you liking school?
Okay?    You're playing in a Bowl Game.
Good.
No.
I'm not picturing things anymore. And when I do, I can just shut it off.
Yeah. Especially Sam. I'm going to ask her out at New Years. I think the time is right now.
How long does this take to work?
I have to get this driveway clean. Then, I have to congratulate you for being happy because you deserve it.
Sam, you ever think that if people knew how crazy you really were, no one would ever talk to you?
No one pressured me into anything. I would never do drugs, officer. Never.
Well, um... I was really tired, and uh...
Not, uh... Not really.
It was a Christmas present.
Did you have fun on your break?
But they said in health class--
Are you sure?
Maybe I could join the cast as an alternate or something?
That'd be great. Thanks.
The one where the girl asks the guy.
You want to go with me?
Are you having a good time?
I don't know. This is my first date, so I don't know what to compare it to.
I'm sorry Craig didn't come.
I don't know. If you like it, he should come.
I'll try not to make you too jealous.
This is sure a nice house.
This merlot is really fancy.
I guess.    Where are your parents?
That's sure a nice fire.
Yeah.
Is it?
Uh-huh?
Uh-huh.
I think so.
Yeah.
Dear Friend... I'm sorry I haven't written for awhile, but things are a total disaster.
I probably should have been honest about how I didn't want to go out with Mary Elizabeth after Sadie's, but I really didn't want to hurt her feelings.
You see, Mary Elizabeth is a really nice person underneath the part of her that hates everyone. And since I heard that having a girlfriend makes you happy, I tried hard to love her like I love Sam.
I know.
So, I took her on double dates.
And I tried not to mind that she loves to hold hands even when her hands are sweaty.
And I had to admit something really upsetting. But I am tired of touching her boobs. I thought maybe if she would just let me pick the make-out music once in awhile, we might have a chance.
And maybe if she didn't put down the books that Mr. Anderson gives me.
Or if she would stop calling me the minute I get home from school when I have absolutely nothing to talk about other than the bus ride home...
I can do that?
I know I should have been honest, but I was getting so mad, it was starting to scare me.
Um... Mary Elizabeth. Can I talk to you--
I just wish I could have found another way to break up. In hindsight, I probably could not have picked a worse way to be honest with Mary Elizabeth.
Truth.
It's so bad that I keep fantasizing that one of us is dying of cancer, so I don't have to break up with her.
Dare.
Mary Elizabeth, I'm sorry.     I'm--
Sam?! Sam! I'm sorry. I didn't mean anything by it. I'm sorry.
But, I... I'm sorry... I didn't mean to do anything.
Oh. Okay. How long do you think?
I'll... I'll be there in a minute.
Mary Elizabeth... I... uh... I've been listening to the Billie Holiday CD every night and--
I know. I just feel really bad about what I did. I just get so messed up inside like I'm - not there or something.
I know. I'm sorry. I just.     We've all become such good friends--
Oh. Yeah. I mean I don't want to do anything to ruin our--
Okay.   I will. Goodbye, Mar--
Something's wrong with me--
No.   He told me to stay away.
Why? Why? What happened?
Are you okay?
If you touch my friends again, I'll blind you.
Yeah?
Sure, Brad.
I don't know. I keep trying, but... I can't really remember what I did.
Yeah.
So, you're not scared of me?
And can we be friends again?
I'm just glad you're happy.
Sure, Patrick.
It kind of is. It so is.
I don't know.
Maybe.
I don't know.
Ew!   That's disgusting!
Uh. Well... there was this girl named Second Base Stace. She had boobs in the 4th grade--
And she let some of the boys feel them.
No.
Fine!    Okay. Your turn.
I don't know.
Yeah.
It's alright.
I've been spending a lot of time with Patrick. He begins every night really excited.
He always says he feels free, and tonight is his destiny. But after awhile, he runs out of things to keep himself numb.
Then, Sam got her letter from Penn State.
But he wasn't going to leave without organizing the best senior prank ever.
Sam is going to leave right after graduation. It all feels very exciting; I just wish it were happening to me.
Especially because ever since I blacked out in the cafeteria, it's been getting worse. And I can't turn it off this time.
Yeah. So, uh, I know it's none of my business, but have you decided... are you going to New York?
Yeah.   Yeah.
Really?
You're the best teacher I ever had.

Dear Friend... I wanted to tell you about us running. There was this beautiful sunset. And just a few hours before, everyone I love had their last day of high school ever. And I was happy because they were happy, even though I counted, and I have 1,095 days to go.
And then there was Sam...
She made it. This is her time. And no one should be able to take that away.
Congratulations.
At her going away party, I wanted her to know about that night we went through the tunnel. And how for the first time, I felt like I belonged somewhere.
And tomorrow, she's leaving. So, I wanted to give her a part of me.
Sure. My brother said Penn State has a restaurant called Ye Olde College Diner.
Yeah. Pretty soon, you'll have a whole new group of friends, and you won't even think about this place anymore.
Yeah?
We accept the love we think we deserve.
I, uh, I just didn't think you wanted that.
I just want you to be happy.
I know who you are, Sam.

I know I'm quiet, and I know I should speak more, but if you knew the things that were in my head most of the time, you'd know what it really meant. How much we are alike. And how we've been through the same things. And you're not small. You're beautiful.
Oh, ah... nothing.
Stop crying.
Stop crying.
It'll be our little secret.
Hey, Candace.
Sam and Patrick left, and um, I just can't stop thinking something.
Candace, I killed Aunt Helen, didn't I?
And I can't stop her.   I'm crazy again.
I was just thinking... what if I wanted her to die, Candace?
Where am I?
You have to let me go.    My dad can't afford it.
No. I saw them when I was little. And I don't want to be a Mayview kid. Just tell me how to stop it.
Seeing it. All their lives. All the time. Just... how do you stop seeing it?
There is so much pain.    And I don't know how to not notice it.
No! Not me. It's them. It's everyone.
What about her?
Yes, she had a terrible life.   But... I mean, what am I...
I don't care.
She was... insane.
Okay.
I, uh... I remember leaving Sam's house, and walking home...
I was in the hospital for awhile. I won't go into detail about all of it. But I will say there were some very bad days.
The worst day was the time my doctor told my mom and dad what Aunt Helen did to me.

The best days were those when I could have visitors. My brother and sister always came for those until Chris had to go to training camp. He's going to be first string this year. And my sister told me she met a nice guy at her summer job.
My doctor said we can't choose where we can come from, but we can choose where we go from there. I know it's not all the answers, but it was enough to start putting these pieces together.
How do you think the Penguins are going to do this year, dad?
What do the players call a puck again?
Definitely.

I don't know if I will have the time to write any more letters because I might be too busy trying to participate. So, if this does end up being the last letter, I just want you to know that I was in a bad place before I started high school. And you helped me.
Even if you didn't know what I was talking about. Or know someone who's gone through it. It made me not feel alone.
I know these will all be stories someday.
Hop, freshman toads. Hop!    Move it, boys!
Hey, Freshman Toad.
Man, you got big.
Worked out all summer.   Rock hard, dude.
Oops.   Sorry, Nothing.
Would you guys get a room?
Who is that kid?
They say that about LSD to scare you.
Charlie, you're fine, man.
No way. There are people out here.
What are you talking about?
Why would I?
This is pathetic, man.    Your fixation on me.
I got jumped in a parking lot.
I don't know what kind of sick shit you're trying to pull.
But you better walk away now... Nothing.
Whatever... faggot.
I called you a faggo--
Charlie?
Thanks for stopping them.
Seniors only.
What are you doing with a plastic spork?
Derek, you're Earth Club Treasurer.
"--make friends in the real world."
Charlie, do you want this?
He gives me one every week.
Maybe your mom and I should have a "drive us to our hair appointment" contest.
Do you always want to be a mama's boy?
Yes! You are! Every time I go to your house--
And you just stand there like a little bitch dog.
Charlie, just go. I can handle it.   Just don't wake up mom and dad.
Look, I egged him on. You saw it. He's never hit me before. I promise he'll never hit me again.
Charlie... this is Pony Tail Derek.   I can handle him. Will you trust me?
Hey, Chris.
Hello.
Charlie?
What?
Call the police and send them to my house.
No, Charlie, listen to me. Mom and dad are going to be home with Chris any second.
What?    Charlie... Charlie!
Are you sure it's not a "God damn biscuit?"
I don't want to bring back silverware--
Mmmm. This chicken paprikash is delicious, Mrs. Kelmeckis.
Freshman year is tough, but you really find yourself.
I hope you love the mix I made.     The cover is hand-painted.
Hey, Babe. This next one might be a little sad, but it reminded me of your eyes.
I'm sorry. I can't do anything about it.
There's nothing I can do--
I am not a mama's boy--
Shhh.   Shut u--
SHUT UP, CANDACE!
But you know what happened? That prick punch killed my best friend in a Saigon whorehouse.
My name is Patrick. You call me Patrick or you call me nothing.
Oh, wow. This is useful guys. We should read on.
I would happily not take shop...
Come on Devils! Woooooo!
Suck it, virginity pledges!
Hey! You're in my shop class, right?
Yeah. Mine looks like a boat.
You want to sit over here, or are you waiting for your friends?
Thanks for not calling me "Nothing" by the way. It's an endless nightmare. And these assholes actually think they're being original.
Love it.
Hey, Sam.
Yes, they call it the men's room.
Party tonight?
He's never tossing that salad.
This is...
Kelmeckis! No shit! Your sister dates Pony Tail Derek, doesn't she?
I try, Sam. I try.
So, what's the plan, Sam? You want to go to Mary Elizabeth's house?
Hey... we're going to Kings after the game if you want to come.
That works on so many levels.
Not a band, Charlie.
I used to be popular before Sam got me some good music. So, watch out, Charlie.
Let it go!     Jesus!   It's an old joke!
Yeah. Call it Slut and The Falcon.      Make us solve crimes.
But Sam's not bitter.     Make no mistake.
She just really believes in bulimia.
Thanks for paying, Charlie.
Bye, Charlie.
Holy shit. They are!   They're playing good music!
Living room routine!
But you wore that toasty costume. It's not like you're trying too hard to be original.
"He's sensitive."
You're a hopeless stoner who attends the culinary institute. So, I'm going to have to say "no" on that one, but nice try. Charlie?
Charlie... this is a party.
This is what fun looks like.
You ready to meet some desperate women?
Here, have a seat. Hey, ladies, meet Charlie. Charlie, meet ladies.
This is Charlie's first party ever. So, I expect nice, meaningful, heartfelt blow jobs from both of you.
Where the hell did you go?
You're so selfish. We looked everywhere for you. You could have told someone.
I think you're doing something wrong.
Charlie?
Relax. Relax. He's a friend of mine.
I know you saw something, but it's okay.
Listen, Brad doesn't want anyone to know... wait, are you baked?
Okay, Charlie, listen. I need you to promise that you're not going to say anything to anyone about me and Brad.
Thank you.     We'll talk later.
Everyone.     Raise your glasses to Charlie.
You didn't do anything. We just want to toast our new friend.
You see things. And you understand.
What is it? What's wrong?
Well, we didn't think there were any cool people left to meet. So, everyone...
Right?    I have no idea.
Sam, it's freezing.
No.     Mama Patrick says no.
Alright! I concede!
Don't worry. She does it all the time.
You got it, your highness.
What?
Whatever happened to Fae Wray? That delicate, satin draped frame? As it clung to her thigh, how I started to cry 'cause I wanted to be dressed just the same.
Give yourself over to absolute pleasure.
I don't know.
I just hope she stops playing dumb with these guys. I keep telling her... don't make yourself small. You can't save anybody.
If you fail me, you get me next semester.
Woo! C Minus! It's over! It's over!
Impossible!
I'll tell you, Sam. This one's tough. I have received a harmonica, a magnetic poetry set, a book about Harvey Milk, and a mix with the song "Asleep" on it...

I mean, I have no idea. This collection of presents is so gay that I think I must have given them to myself. But despite that distinct possibility, I'm going to have to go with... drum roll... Charlie.
Huh.   Now, why do you say that?
Well, you'll be surprised to know that your secret santa is actually... me.
Because all the great writers used to wear great suits. Your last present is on a towel rack in the bathroom. Delve into our facilities. Emerge a star.
Mary Elizabeth, why are you trying to eat Christmas? Hand them out, Sam.
Yeah!   What a display of man I have ever seen!
Thanks. And Charlie... since you were born on Christmas Eve, I figure you don't get a lot of birthday presents. So, I thought you should have my clock. From the heart.
I love you guys!
Who are you talking to?
Get ready, breeder.
Excuse me, everyone, but you're missing some hot "fag on goth" action.
Okay. My turn. Um... let's think...
How is your first relationship going?
Charlie?   Truth or dare?
I dare you to kiss the prettiest girl in the room on the lips. Notice I charitably said girl and not person because let's face it... I'd smoke all you bitches.
Now that's fucked up.
Trust me.    You don't want to go back there.
I know you didn't, but look... I hate to be the one to break this, but there's history with Mary Elizabeth and Sam.
Not now, Charlie. I'm sorry.
You going to do something?
Your pet ape just tripped me.    Are you going to say something?
You know why.
Do you want your friends to know how you got those bruises? Really?
Where? In Schenley Park? Do they know about Schenley Park?
Do you guys know about Schenley Park?
Fine.   Say hi to your dad for me.
What did you call me?
Say that shit again!    Say that shit again!
Hey Craig, Sam will be down soon.
Hey... you wanna get out of here?

I'll tell you something, Charlie. I feel good. You know what I mean? Maybe tomorrow I'll take you to this karaoke place downtown. And this club off the strip. They don't card. And the Schenley Park scene. You gotta see the "fruit loop" at least one time.
Oh, my God. My life is officially an after school special. Son of a bitch!
So, you ever hear the one about Lily Miller?
Really? I thought your brother would have told you. It's a classic.
So, Lily comes here with this guy Parker.
They did it with one of the sandwich bags.
Yes! It is! Let's keep the train rolling. Suburban legends. Charlie!
Mosquito bites. Promising.     Go.
That's your suburban legend?     Did you at least cop a feel?
Of course not. You went home, listened to "Asleep," wrote a poem about her self-
Yeah, I've got one. Well, there was this one guy. Queer as a 3 dollar bill.
Why can't you save anybody?
Forget it. I'm free now, right? I could meet the love of my life any second now.
I'm sorry.
"We will require you to take our summer session at the main campus immediately following your high school graduation."
She got in, Charlie.
Oh, Charlie's here! Guys, group photo!
Yeah, this is the one. That's going to be a great angle.
Can Charlie come out and play?
Sorry, Sam. Charlie has a breakdown scheduled for October.
Nice Trapper Keeper, faggot.
Nice look, jag off.
Shhh. I'm Mr. Anderson. And thanks to Teach for America, I'm going to be your teacher for freshman English. This semester, we're going to be learning Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird.
I'm shocked. Alright. You can skip the quiz if you tell me which author invented the paperback book. Anyone?
He's British. He also invented the serial. In fact, at the end of chapter 3 of his first novel, he had a man hanging off a cliff by his fingernails. Hence, the term cliffhanger. Anybody?
That's a great guess, but no, Shakespeare didn't write novels. Anybody else?
The author was...

... Charles Dickens. However, if you and I had gone to a play in Shakespeare's time, it would have cost 4 pennies. Can you imagine that? We would have put those pennies in a metal box, which the ushers would lock in the office. And that's where we get the term... anyone?
I'll give you a free "A" on anything but the final term paper if you get it right.
Box office.
You should learn to participate.
Why didn't you raise your hand?
They call you teacher's pet? Freak?
I used to get spaz. I mean, come on, spaz?
So, I heard you had a tough time last year. But they say if you make one friend on your first day, you're doing okay.
Yeah.   I could see that.
Wow.    That was fast.   You want another one?
Yeah.
Are we talking about anyone specific?
We accept the love we think we deserve.
We can try.
Charlie... this was my favorite book growing up. This is my copy, but I want you to have it.
Have a great Christmas break.
More fun than you're going to have today, Sinatra.
Guys, you want to pass your copies of Gatsby up to the front please? And I know it's the last day, but if we could just keep it to a dull roar, I'd appreciate it.
Thank you for such a great year. I had a blast. I hope you did, too. And I hope you have a great time this summer on your vacations. Now, who here is going to be reading for pleasure this summer?
Very good, Charlie. Who else?
Last day.
Well, my wife and I like it here, and I think I might be better at teaching than writing.
So, uh Charlie... I was thinking maybe I could still give you books next year.
I think you could write one of them one day.
I do.
Thank you.
Shakespeare.
"Office Depot!" "Office Supplies!"
Charlie, come on.
Thank you, Derek. It's Charlie's favorite. He was a little nervous about starting high school, so I made it.
I think you could be a little nicer to Derek.
Hey, look who's here...
10 pounds... Weight Watchers.
Make a wish, honey.
You're seeing things again, Charlie?
You must be Mary Elizabeth.    It's so good to meet you.
She's on the phone right now? Charlie, you have to break up with her.
We're going to be late for Easter Mass.
Honey?
I'm so sorry.
You feel a little silly being nervous now, huh, champ?
I told you. Just give 'em a smile and be yourself. That's how you--
You're cruisin' for a bruisin'.
Thanks, Derek.
I'm sorry.     The kid's a pussy.   I can't stand him.
20 dollars? What do you want 10 dollars for?
Have fun.
Hey!   Look who's here!
Charlie tells me you're a Buddhist.
OK, a little closer together. That looks nice. Buddhist, I need you to smile a little bit more. There you go. Nice.
For Christ's sake... I need to use the phone!
God bless this food that we are about to receive. We thank You for this bounty in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ. Amen.
God damn Penguins. I think they're allergic to God damn defense.
A biscuit.
You're cruisin' for a bruisin'.
Hey, Nothing. Hey, Nothing.
Question. Could the bathrooms here be more disgusting?
Well, I finally got hold of Bob.
No. He's still trying to shag that waitress from the Olive Garden.
Patrick... who's this?
Awww. Leave Pony Tail Derek alone.    You put the "ass" in "class," Patrick.
It's nice to meet you, Charlie.    I'm Sam.
Can't. She got caught watering down her parent's brandy with iced tea. Let's just go to Kings.
Do you have a favorite band?
Are you kidding!? I love The Smiths!
Thanks. What about Eide's?     You love Eide's, right?
It's an old record store downtown.
So, Charlie... what are you going to do when you get out of here?
You could write about us.
He's my step-brother. My mom finally left my worthless dad and married his nice dad 3 years ago.

I love bulimia.
God, would you turn that down? You're going to make us deaf. Bye, Charlie.
